citation.article-title: Bifidobacterium ruminantium sp. nov. and Bifidobacterium merycicum sp. nov. from the rumens of cattle.

p.s: Description of Bifidobacterium ruminantium sp, nov.
Bifidobacterium ruminantium (ru.mi.nan´ti.um. L. gen. pl. part. n. ruminantium, of ruminants)

Gram-positive, nonmotile, nonsporeforming cells (length, 3.0 to 6.0 μm) that are irregular in shape, rarely have terminal bifurcations, and often occur in pairs which form wide angles (Fig. 9 through 12).
Surface colonies on Trypticase-Phytone-yeast extract agar are soft, smooth, convex, circular with entire margins, cream to white, and glistening (Fig. 14).
Anaerobic.
Carbon dioxide has no effect upon oxygen sensitivity, but it enhances anaerobic growth.
The optimum temperature for growth is 38 to 42°C.
No growth occurs below 25°C or at 45°C and above.
The optimum initial pH is 6.5 to 6.9.
Growth is delayed at pH 6.3 or 7.2.
No growth occurs at pH 4.5 or 8.
Raffinose, sucrose, glucose, melibiose, mannitol, maltose, lactose, fructose, galactose, starch, dextrin, and ribose are fermented.
Arabinose, xylose, mannose, melezitose, sorbitol, trehalose, cellobiose, glycerin, rhamnose, gluconate, lactate, and inulin are not fermented.
Salicin fermentation does not occur or, occasionally, is slow.
The molar ratio of lactic acid to acetic acid from the fermentation of glucose ranges from 1:2 to 1:3.
No gas, propionic acid, or butyric acid is produced.
Catalase or pseudocatalase (hemin) is not produced.
Nitrate is not reduced.
Indole is not produced.
The G+C content of the DNA is 57 mol% (strains Ru679, Ru687T, and Ru728) or 58 mol% (strain Ru666) (as determined by the thermal denaturation method).
The level of DNA relatedness to B. adolescentis is greater than the level of DNA relatedness to any other species of the genus.
The type strain is strain Ru687 (= ATCC 49390), which was isolated from bovine rumen.
